awd_titl_txt: RII Track-1: Microbiomes of Aquatic, Plant, and Soil Systems across Kansas
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
Microbiome science, the study of the combined genetic material from the set of all microorganism taxa present in a particular environment, is increasingly seen as important for addressing ecological questions, including societal challenges such as sustaining agricultural production while maintaining soil and water quality. This project will undertake a large survey of plant, soil and aquatic microbiomes and their environmental characteristics to catalog these communities and assess the ability of microbiomes to influence crop production, soil condition and water quality. Kansas is an ideal natural laboratory for this project due to the large gradients in precipitation and land use across the state. The project team will integrate its research and educational activities to improve Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education capacity in both urban and rural areas, among mainstream, economically disadvantaged, and first-generation college students, enhance the participation of Native Americans and other under-represented groups, and to expand the workforce in microbial, plant, and soil science, genomics, bioinformatics and ecology.

Technical Description 
This project is synergistic with the 2016 White House Initiative to improve understanding of microbiomes. Major project goals are to: develop a mechanistic understanding of microbiome-mediated ecosystem functions, predict ecosystem responses to changes in precipitation and land-use patterns, and identify ways to select for and utilize microbiomes to produce desired characteristics such as increased agricultural productivity or drought tolerance, efficient nutrient utilization, and enhanced soil quality. Advanced molecular techniques, including massively parallel sequencing of DNA, amplicon sequencing, and metatranscriptomic analyses, will be utilized in conjunction with large-scale field and greenhouse experiments. Databases will be created to link metagenomic data with environmental parameters across the state and identify genotypes that may confer desired responses under varying conditions. Data will be analyzed using standard statistical techniques and advanced methods such as structural equation modeling. Results will be used to identify practices to maximize plant productivity, water quality, and soil health.

por.por_cntn:
The Kansas NSF EPSCoR RII Track-1 project titled, Microbiomes of Aquatic, Plant, and Soil Systems across Kansas (MAPS), involved collaborating researchers from the University of Kansas, Kansas State University, Wichita State University, Fort Hays State University, and Haskell Indian Nations University. By creating a comprehensive experimental and observational network, the team built capacity across the state for studying microbiomes of land and waterways. Given its large differences in precipitation and agricultural land, Kansas served as an ideal location for these experiments.

The team's mission was driven by a vision that one day microbiomes can be leveraged to manage ecosystems and solve environmental challenges related to crop production, drought tolerance, soil condition, and water quality. Major project goals included developing a mechanistic understanding of microbiome-mediated ecosystem functions; predicting ecosystem responses to changes in precipitation and land-use patterns; and identifying ways to use microbiomes for crop and other ecological benefits. Additionally, MAPS science underpins the function and supply of freshwater ecosystem services that are crucial to Kansas' water needs.

Aquatic Microbiome Thrust researchers designed an experimental approach to better understand the riparian zone - areas of vegetation that border streams. These areas filter pollutants and other materials that wash down from higher areas into streams during storms. Before MAPS began, we knew little about the way materials move through riparian zones during storms. By developing a method to simulate rain on the riparian zone, MAPS researchers can now characterize movement of materials into streams, revealing that ammonium removal, for example, was highly efficient in the riparian zone of a tallgrass prairie stream, and ammonium uptake in the stream channel was also significant. This approach is central to the project's goals of linking habitats, and the team has applied its methodology across the project. Moreover, several publications are serving as data / proof-of-concept for future grant proposals.

Plant Microbiome Thrust researchers used various methods, such as a highly targeted approach to analyzing genetic variation known as Amplicon sequencing to make several discoveries. For example, researchers uncovered a link between the plants' homesite and the specific local microbes. The results support a hypothesis known as the "home field advantage," where the unique homesite microbes may represent microbial specialists that are linked to plant stress responses. These results improve understanding of the complex interplay between plant host and soil microbes, which should open doors for further inquiry into the functional potential of recruited microbes.

Soil Microbiome Thrust researchers published a host of significant findings, including demonstrating that altered soil structure in agricultural soils influences the steepness of the decline in soil organic carbon with depth, and that this phenomenon is modulated by the annual incoming precipitation. The team also discovered a novel finding showing how anaerobic microsites play a significant role in the soil organic carbon response to precipitation and in the accrual of carbon during the restoration of grasslands after the cessation of row crop agriculture. Researchers developed reactive transport models that describe how modified rooting depths and precipitation regimes can result in altered water flow patterns and fluxes of dissolved organic carbon throughout watersheds - findings that are helping project ecosystem functioning and management strategies for addressing major concerns about the Earth's changing climate.  

Synthesis Thrust researchers developed equation models to begin to synthesize aquatic, plant, and soil data. The team first focused on models predicting plant community composition and soil carbon. Then data from terrestrial sites were integrated with data from aquatic sites and used to test the models. These samples also enable parameterization of reactive transport models and analysis of dynamical models. Given the huge volume of data, the team has compiled the datasets in a repository for continued analysis and discovery.

This project has generated more than 90 articles in scholarly journals. It has led to 45 external awards amounting to more than $35 million in funding. It has engaged more than 70 college students in research, created two new college courses, and hired four faculty members, bolstering expertise at the participating universities.

The research was integrated with outreach that significantly broadened participation in science. For example, the project brought science directly to a total of 54 elementary classrooms, with four to seven visits per class, enhancing the education of more than 1000 students with ecosystem curricula tied to national standards and seven YouTube videos, each delivered in English and Spanish. 55 secondary teachers across the state were also supported by the program. Finally, 53 Native American interns received training in research that relates directly to their tribal communities.
